awd_titl_txt: New Methodological Developments for Inference in the Regression-Discontinuity Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the development of new methods for the statistical analysis of social science data.  The project focuses on 'regression discontinuity' (RD) models, which are very widely used in practice.  This kind of statistical model is used to estimate the effect of a treatment on an outcome when unobserved factors may threaten the validity of the statistical analysis.  While RD models are widely used to analyze data, many important methodological and statistical features of the models are not well understood.  This project develops novel methods for the analysis of RD models and applies the results to concrete empirical problems in Economics and other social sciences.

The research develops new methodological and practical tools for estimation, inference and falsification of RD designs.  This includes a method that accounts for the fact that RD estimators are sensitive to the choice of bandwidth, a method that is valid in finite samples, the analysis of RDs with multiple cutoffs and the development of new tools for spatial RD designs.

Broader impacts of this research will come from the use of these new methods to provide better insight for economic policy.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant focused on the development of new methods for the statistical analysis of micro-level data employing the 'regression discontinuity' (RD) design, a research strategy widely used in practice across many disciplines in the social, behavioral, biomedical, and statistical sciences. RD designs are used to estimate the effect of a treatment/policy/intervention on an outcome of interest when unobserved factors may threaten the validity of the statistical analysis. While RD models are widely used in empirical work for research and policy purposes, many important methodological and statistical features are still not well understood. This fact undermines the validity and transparency of empirical results obtained using RD designs, and could seriously affect policy decisions based on them.

The main objective of this grant was to develop novel methods for the analysis and interpretation of RD models and to apply the results to concrete empirical problems in Economics and other social, behavioral and biomedical sciences. The goals included not only theoretical and methodological results, but also numerical methods and general-purpose software. The latter is particularly important because it greatly enhances replicability and reproducibility of empirical work employing RD designs, in addition to offering a general common benchmark for employing RD designs in practice.

The key intellectual merits of this grant centered around developing new methodological and practical tools for estimation, inference and falsification of RD designs. In particular, this included a method that accounts for the fact that RD estimators are sensitive to the choice of bandwidth, a method that is valid in finite samples, the interpretation of RD designs with multiple cutoffs, and the development of new tools for spatial RD designs. Broader impacts of this research came from the use of these new methods to provide better insight for economic and social policy.

Results from this grant include:

1) 21 published papers, software articles, book chapters, and other publications.

2) 1 published edited volume on RD designs methods, and an associated 2-day conference. Website: https://sites.google.com/site/aie38rdd/

3) 4 general-purpose software packages for RD analysis in R and Stata, two of the most common statistical software platforms for empirical work and policy analysis. Website: https://sites.google.com/site/rdpackages/

4) 5 Ph.D. students trained, all coauthors in several papers and software packages.

5) 25+ short courses on RD methods and program evaluation for policy-makers and impact evaluators (see PIs' websites for details).

6) Creation, coordination and promotion of the Interdisciplinary Seminar in Quantitative Methods (ISQM) at the University of Michigan. Website: http://www.isr.umich.edu/cps/events/isqm/

The output from this grant has already had an important impact in empirical and policy work employing RD designs. Some of the products mentioned above have received multiple awards, and are highly cited and referenced in both academic and public policy circles. The general-purpose software for RD analysis is by now the default software used by practitioners in many fields of study.
